text: in the last episode my dad and I began
construction of a snowmobile camper
today we're going to finish it
as we travel to the cabin site we
inspected the trails along the way we
wanted to make sure that all obstacles
were removed in preparation for the sled
shelters maiden voyage
aside from this small Creek the trail
was clear
as small as it was however we were
concerned that the sharp dip into the
creek might cause the camper to nose in
and become stuck so we decided to build
a small winter bridge over it to start
we needed to gather some materials back
at the cabin site we broke some poplar
scabs free from the snow I had been
saving them for just such an occasion
[Music]
I can take over and shovel too if you
want here while you save your energy
[Music]
[Applause]
with the winter bridge taken care of
we returned our efforts to the sled
camper
[Music]
[Music]
that's pretty nice yeah
okay okay I got a screw higher - that's
great I think whenever for the supports
now I'll have it always on a bit of a
slant and not my own in bread or wood
stove the heat will travel up and into
the half the bunkhouse here good
[Applause]
I installed a vent hole in one of the
gable ends ventilation is important in
this case because it will keep moisture
from collecting and condensing on the
inside
we made the door swing upward so that it
can double as an awning the only problem
with this setup is that it's difficult
to get into and out of the solution to
our door dilemma was a pair of lift
supports
during the winter months in the bush
darkness comes quick and complete since
the day was getting on we knew that it
wouldn't be much longer until the Sun
slipped beneath the horizon this is
normally when we would pack up and head
out for the day but I decided to remain
a little longer in order to put the
finishing touches on the camper so I
told Dad out on the dogsled and returned
to the camper on my own
[Applause]
[Music]
[Music]
well the snowmobile camper is pretty
much complete and I couldn't be happier
with how it turned out I'm not sure if
you can hear a bit of the noise outside
but it is a little windy but I am 100%
protected in here I'm not getting any
drafts or anything which is great and
that's due to the reflective foam board
insulation that I have installed it's on
the floor the walls and the ceiling as
well and that has helped to keep the
heat in but I have also installed a vent
hole at the top here so that moisture
can't escape and it doesn't build up
inside here what's nice about the
reflective surface on this foam board
insulation is that it not only reflects
heat but it reflects light and so these
two LED light strips that I have in here
led up the place really well and they
use only a little bit of power and
that's because the light is bouncing
around inside and it's amplified I have
to say that my favorite feature about
the snowmobile campers so far are the
lift supports that my dad and I
installed they have worked so well
what's nice about it is that it not only
lifts the door up but we've installed it
at such an angle that when we're closing
the door it also seals the door shut too
so they hold the door closed just by the
power of these lift supports and so the
great news about that is that we haven't
had to install any latches on the
outside or on the inside the door is
held shut completely by the strength of
these lift supports and I know some of
you may comment that as you've seen the
door open it opens hi
it doesn't an open level or on a down
tilt and originally I was hoping to have
the door open with a bit of a
own tilt so that if I'm having a
campfire or something outside that the
heat will rise into the camper with a
slope of the door but the reason why I
decided to eventually just have the door
open right up is because it's so much
easier just to get out that way if the
door was slanted downward then it would
be a lot harder to get out of so it was
nice just to have it open all the way up
and access in and out is very easy and
for the most part if I want to heat this
place I'm hoping just to do it mainly
with body heat when I stay here
overnight eventually I want to bring a
hot water bottle and have that heating
myself and the space as well but at
while I'm in here I don't want to have
any candles burning I don't want to want
to have any flames anything like that
and that should be just because the
space is too cramped for anything like
that it would just be too unsafe I have
made it so that there's just enough
space for me to lay down here so the
idea is that this space will be heated
mainly with my body heat and so when I
stay here overnight in the future we'll
see how well that works out I've also
had some other ideas as to how to heat
this place without using flames or
anything like that and so I've got a few
ideas in my head and maybe I'll
implement them in the future
but so I love the LED light strips as
well I think those are so cool and I
think what I'll do in the future or what
I would like to do is install maybe a
solar panel on the roof and that way we
can have my power bank back here being
charged on a regular basis and powering
the lights which would be great the only
downside of having a solar panel on the
roof is that it will likely be covered
with snow and I'll have to constantly be
clearing it to have it charge properly
so we'll see if I install a solar panel
that's just coming to extra that I may
or may not do as I made supper this
evening what I did to help start the
heating process in the shelter here is
that I lit about six candles and just
left them here with the door shut and
that did help I think it raised the
temperature in here about eight degrees
it's minus 4 degrees outside right now
and it raised the temperature to 4
degrees Celsius in here I'm not sure
what the conversion for that is in
Fahrenheit but you'll have to excuse my
Canadian but now that I've jumped in
here after supper my body heat is
actually risen the temperature further
and it's continuing to climb so as I'm
talking right now the thermostat is
saying that it is minus 4 degrees
outside and it is plus 8 degrees inside
and I might as well do the conversion
here and that would be 25 degrees
Fahrenheit outside and 46 degrees
Fahrenheit inside so there you go it is
actually fairly warm in here I still
have my winter gear on but I'm quite hot
right now so I think if I had a sleeping
bag in here and and some blankets I
would be more than cozy and maybe even a
little too hot if I had too many layers
which is good news it shows that I can
be quite comfortable in here overnight
during the winter time after spending
approximately 45 minutes in the winter
camper the inside temperature had risen
to 10 degrees Celsius while the outside
temperature remained at minus 4 degrees
Celsius
that translates to 49 degrees Fahrenheit
inside and 25 degrees Fahrenheit outside
I'd like to say a big thank you to
thrunite for sponsoring this episode I'm
very particular with sponsors on this
channel in fact through night is the
only sponsor that I've ever allowed to
be on this channel that I've ever been
willing to work with and that's because
I personally believe in their product
and their flashlights have really helped
me a lot as I'm getting out of the bush
at nighttime or doing some work in the
dark earlier on in this episode you may
have seen some footage of me with one of
their headlamps on and that is an
invaluable tool for me and as well as
this flashlight that they just sent me
this is the TC 15 and you can see how
small it is here it pretty much fits in
the palm of my hand this is currently at
the time of filming the most powerful
EDC flashlight on the market to the best
of my knowledge this is 2,300
my camera battery cut out on me but I
said pretty much everything I wanted to
bottom-line through night makes a
product that I can get behind they're
bright they last and they're tough
what's more I rely on them especially on
nights like these when I wouldn't be
able to see my hand in front of my face
without them anyway now that the
snowmobile camper is complete I look
forward to taking it on the journey
ahead but I've done all I can do for
today I figure this is a good a time as
any to showcase just how powerful the
little TC 15 flashlight is especially
when it is compared against the
brightness of the snowmobile headlight
just like all through night flashlights
the TC 15 is impact resistant and
waterproof it also comes with a holster
battery and clip
if you're to shop around you will see
that the TC 15 also sells on average for
$30 less than any other comparable
high-end EC flashlight that's out there
anyway that's it for now
until next time my friends
